data.title: [theme] make token colors user customizable
data.body:
Like the workbench colors, it should be possible to also extend (or replace) the current token colors.

This could be part of `workbench.colorCustomizations` or a separate setting `editor.tokenColorsCustomizations`.

Internally, coloring of tokens is based on textmate coloring rules. As textmate scopes are an advanced topic (what scopes to use where), we should think of also offering a simple mode where users can set colors to predefined concepts like 'comment, 'strings' 'numbers', 'types'....

data.title: Language Service crash & restart doesn't trigger Language Server's onExit and onShutdown, and register provider multiple times
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: OS X 10.11.6

For this file: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/blob/master/extensions/html/server/src/htmlServerMain.ts

If I add `connection.onExit` or `connection.onShutdown`, none of them will be triggered for server crash & restart.

Manually triggered server crash. Notice none of `exit` or `shutdown` is logged:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/26709072/f4c4d988-471d-11e7-8d9a-78c98ffc7b95.png)

Also, the closed connection does not clear registered providers. And restart & re-registration causes multiple providers to be registered. For example, the `hoverProvider`:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/4033249/26709084/137bad70-471e-11e7-808b-9d510dba694a.png)

This is the root cause of https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/25275#issuecomment-296997278, https://github.com/octref/vetur/issues/110 and https://github.com/octref/vetur/issues/184.

I didn't find any way to unregister providers registered by previous providers, and I think closed connection should dispose all its registered providers by default.

@dbaeumer @aeschli

data.title: Render reference results as they are returned by reference providers.
data.body:
This prevents a slow reference provider from blocking the results of other reference providers.

This PR is useful by itself, but it also resolves UX issues related to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/20010 and gives us a starting point to implement streaming further down the stack.

Before
![before](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/754768/26705836/9fe74296-46ed-11e7-931f-ee74ad7583a4.gif)

After (edit: updated screenshot with progress bar)
![progress3](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/754768/26809599/e7fcae1a-4a1a-11e7-9a2c-07db0a233555.gif)

TODO
- [x] Fix no results case

data.title: allow root to run vscode without complaints
data.body:
we install vscode into a docker image running centos  through docker for windows. 

there is only one user at that docker image: root. 

creating another user is not an option because the moby linux vm that runs the docker daemon runs docker as root and we mount the docker client from moby linux into the docker container so that we can control docker from within the docker container. 

And we want to use vscode too inside that docker container through a cygwin X server running in windows. So we do that as root. 

that message "It is recommended not to run Code as 'root'." is very annoying and the fact that you need to always specify code --user-data-dir='.' is also very annoying. 

also, in this scenario, the only way I can reliably run vscode is through `code --user-data-dir='/root'`. any other way is met with hangs and freezes. 

consider creating an option for when the user knows and accepts the consequences of running vscode as root.

data.title: Default text not acting as tab stop
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: Windows

Might be a user error, but

- take the following snippet
```json
"nls-snippet": {
	"prefix": "nls",
	"body": [
		"nls.localize('${1:key}', '${TM_SELECTED_TEXT:value}');$0"
	]
}
```
- insert the snippet without selected text
- press tab

I would expect that value is selected and acts like a tab stop.

- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|

|vscode-eslint|dbaeumer|1.2.11|
|githistory|donjayamanne|0.2.0|
|gitlens|eamodio|3.5.1|
|tslint|eg2|0.15.0|
|vscode-npm-script|eg2|0.1.9|
|php-debug|felixfbecker|1.10.0|
|php-intellisense|felixfbecker|1.3.0|
|php-pack|felixfbecker|1.0.1|
|vsc-travis-ci-status|felixrieseberg|1.1.0|
|file-icons|file-icons|1.0.3|
|vscode-npm|fknop|3.3.0|
|csstriggers|kisstkondoros|0.1.0|
|vscode-apache|mrmlnc|1.1.1|
|mssql|ms-mssql|1.0.0|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.2|
|Theme-MaterialKit|ms-vscode|0.1.4|
|Theme-TomorrowKit|ms-vscode|0.1.4|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.2|
|php-docblocker|neilbrayfield|1.2.0|
|vscode-docker|PeterJausovec|0.0.15|
|vscode-versionlens|pflannery|0.18.1|
|material-icon-theme|PKief|2.0.7|
|vscode-css-peek|pranaygp|1.2.4|
|java|redhat|0.5.0|
|vscode-icons|robertohuertasm|7.8.1|
|stylelint|shinnn|0.24.0|
|vscode-csstree|smelukov|0.1.7|
|arduino-vscode|steveyin|0.2.2|
|Seti-theme|TsumiNa|0.0.1|
|babelrc|waderyan|1.0.0|
|twig|whatwedo|1.0.2|
|html-css-class-completion|Zignd|1.2.1|;

---

A fellow student of mine switched to VS Code after having used Atom. He didn't know Emmet exists, so he wasn't familiar with expansion on tab, he expected 4 spaces to be inserted. After his frustration, I guided him in the settings to turn of Emmet.

A solution I am thinking of would be to ask the user if he or she would like to use Emmet the first time a Emmet compatible file is opened. To give a user more context on what Emmet is, it could be useful to show build in extension in the extension view. The message could have a button which opens the Emmet extension page.
An extension page also solves a second concern. In my experience, for a new user it is weird turning self installed extensions off through the extension view and build in extensions trough settings.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Normal Emmet expansion on tab in an html or php file

data.title: Markdown syntax highlighting should ignore math inside $$
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.2
- OS Version: macOS Sierra 10.12.5

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a markdown document and use inline LaTeX (e.g. `$a_{b}$`) for math.
2. VSCode interprets the markdown underscore to mean italic text -- instead of math subscript -- and will make the markdown text italic until it sees a matching underscore delimiter.

I think this is behavior is theme dependent, but I'm not sure. Changing themes just changes how the text between the underscores is rendered (italic or colored or whatever). I believe that markdown delimiters (`_` and `*`) in math mode should be ignored the way they are in code blocks.

![markdown_latex](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5393995/26690428/1ca09656-46ae-11e7-97f9-b3231b6ad09d.png)
